results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: Noise destroys
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Phillip Mark-Law, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film deals with the effects of industrial noise on hearing. Presented as a dramatic short film, the narrative follows the protagonist, Len, as he discovers he is partially deaf due to twenty years of working with loud machines in a factory and goes on a crusade to improve working conditions. The film is directed at employers as well as employees, showing the importance of wearing safety gear and machines being modified or insulated to limit sound production. The film contains light-hearted moments of comedy, as Len goes about convincing his colleagues and management of the significance of the issue.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Max Cullen, Brian Duhig, Barry Pierce, John Hale, Keith Jarvis, Barrie Muir, Jack Perry, Richard Meredith, Billie Hammerberg, Tony Boden, Kevin Lacey, Don Glover, Tracy Lee, Bob Gunning, Peter Lewis, Matthew Rhodes

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Narwhals came
results.brief_description: Shows records of undersea life made by divers in Arctic waters. Includes photography of the Narwhal whale, sought by hunters for its prized ivory tusk.

results.title: The Melting pot
results.brief_description: A day in the life of the Victoria Market, Melbourne. Begins with the derelicts who haunt the area, the early arrival of delivery trucks and shows the hectic crowds of the market in full swing. Closes with the end of the market day with its inevitable clearing away of refuse and the departure of people.

results.title: Matchmaker at work
results.brief_description: Outlines recent developments in the CRA group, including: - establishment of Hamersley’s second mine complex at Paraburdoo; the Bougainville Copper operation; Comalco’s integrated aluminium group, and integration of lead zinc interests into Australian Mining and Smelting.

results.title: The Man on the beat
results.creator_credit: Patricia Murray, Ralph Kemplen, Roger MacDougall and Merlin Films
results.brief_description: The duties and training of a London policeman, known over the world for his courtesy. The London policeman is unarmed, and his duties vary from finding lost children to directing traffic. Dealing with crime is only an occasional part of the ordinary London policeman’s job.

results.title: Loop
results.creator_credit: R. Barrington Scott and Southern Films
results.brief_description: A documentary about Melbourne’s Underground Rail Loop, its effect on the entire metropolitan railway system, and on the future of public transport in Melbourne. Shows the route the loop tracks and tunnels will follow around the city, the sites for the three new underground stations to supplement the present two stations, how passengers will travel from suburban stations when the loop is operating, how the loop is being constructed, and the benefits for train travellers of having five city stations close to shops, theatres and offices. Photographed by Volk Mol, sound by Don Boardman, edited by Geoff Wright, narrated by Michael Pate. Produced for the Melbourne Underground Rail Loop Authority.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 04
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Kip and David”.
David and his elfin friend Kip discover many surprises while playing in the garden. A green tree frog hidden in a plant, a shady Traveller’s palm and newly grown mushrooms - ideal stools for Kip. As they search for a dry, sheltered home for Kip, they see bearded dragon and frilled lizards. After clearing a site at the foot of a tree, they draw a plan and prepare to build it. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.
